table-wrap.anchoringText: Although, frictional pressure drop is an important consideration in the horizontal well design, heterogeneity largely dictates inflow along lateral. The oil inflow profiles are generally non-uniform (Jha et al., 2009) and oil rates calculated in the flow simulation models were higher in the areas of higher permeability (Figure 17). Some portions of the well did not contribute because of locally poor quality reservoir. These non-contributing zones can occur anywhere along the well. In this well, the percentage of non-contributing zone (~20% for this well) calculated from the model is comparable with the average non-effective well length (as % of drilled length), calculated using the cut-offs presented in Table 1.
table-wrap.label: Table 1
table-wrap.caption: Characteristic density and viscosity ranges of heavy oil, extra heavy oil and bitumen; analogous common fluids

formatted-caption.caption-text: Characteristic density and viscosity ranges of heavy oil, extra heavy oil and bitumen; analogous common fluids

tr.td: olive oil < heavy oil < chocolate mousse or molasses

table-wrap.anchoringText: Gamma ray (GR), resistivity, neutron porosity, and other measurements are available every 0.5 ft. in the lateral section of the well. Porosity, VShale, and water saturation were determined using these well logs for the completed section of each well (Tankersley and Waite, 2002). Cut offs on porosity, VShale and water saturation (Table 2) are applied at each interval where measurements are available to calculate effective well length.
table-wrap.label: Table 2
table-wrap.caption: Cut offs for calculating effective well lengths

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cut offs for calculating effective well lengths

table-wrap.anchoringText: Significant reduction in oil viscosity of heavy and extra heavy oil is also observed due to presence of gas. Live oil viscosity can be up to an order lower than the dead oil viscosity and is a strong function of solution gas oil ratio. The simulation models used in this study use suitable critical gas saturation (range described in Table 3) and relative permeability curves (Sahni et al. 2001) to capture the solution gas drive mechanisms in the reservoir.
table-wrap.label: Table 3
table-wrap.caption: Input Uncertainties

tr.td: Live oil viscosity is a strong function of depth due to variation in temperature with depth.
Horizontal permeability (Kh) mid value of 11000 md was used. Kv. Kh was kept at 0.1.
Horizontal permeability (Kh) was unchanged at mid value.
